questions.question: Who proposed the Five Kingdom Classification system?
questions.explanation: R.H. Whittaker (1969) proposed the Five Kingdom Classification with kingdoms Monera, Protista, Fungi, Plantae and Animalia. (NCERT Page 11)

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a criterion used by Whittaker for Five Kingdom Classification?
questions.explanation: Whittaker used cell structure, body organisation, mode of nutrition, reproduction and phylogenetic relationships as criteria. Habitat was not a primary criterion. (NCERT Page 11)

questions.question: The cell wall of Kingdom Monera is composed of:
questions.explanation: According to NCERT Table 2.1, Monera has noncellulosic cell wall made of polysaccharide + amino acid. (NCERT Page 11)

questions.question: Which kingdom has chitin in its cell wall?
questions.explanation: According to NCERT Table 2.1, Fungi have cell wall present with chitin. Plants have cellulose in their cell walls. (NCERT Page 11)

questions.question: The body organisation in Kingdom Fungi is:
questions.explanation: As per NCERT Table 2.1, Fungi have multicellular/loose tissue body organisation. (NCERT Page 11)

questions.question: Which shape of bacteria is comma-shaped?
questions.explanation: Vibrium (pl.: vibrio) are comma-shaped bacteria. Cocci are spherical, Bacilli are rod-shaped, and Spirilla are spiral. (NCERT Page 12)

questions.question: Archaebacteria that live in extreme salty areas are called:
questions.explanation: Halophiles live in extreme salty areas. Thermoacidophiles live in hot springs, and Methanogens live in marshy areas. (NCERT Page 13)

questions.question: Methanogens are found in the gut of:
questions.explanation: Methanogens are present in the gut of several ruminant animals such as cows and buffaloes and are responsible for production of methane (biogas). (NCERT Page 13)

questions.question: Which pigment is present in cyanobacteria that makes them photosynthetic?
questions.explanation: Cyanobacteria have chlorophyll a similar to green plants and are photosynthetic autotrophs. (NCERT Page 13)

questions.question: Nitrogen fixation in cyanobacteria occurs in specialised cells called:
questions.explanation: Some cyanobacteria can fix atmospheric nitrogen in specialised cells called heterocysts, e.g., Nostoc and Anabaena. (NCERT Page 13)

questions.question: Which of the following organisms completely lack a cell wall?
questions.explanation: Mycoplasma are organisms that completely lack a cell wall. They are the smallest living cells known and can survive without oxygen. (NCERT Page 14)

questions.question: The smallest living cells known are:
questions.explanation: Mycoplasma are the smallest living cells known and can survive without oxygen. (NCERT Page 14)

questions.question: Diatoms belong to which group of protists?
questions.explanation: Chrysophytes include diatoms and golden algae (desmids). They are found in fresh water as well as marine environments. (NCERT Page 14)

questions.question: The cell walls of diatoms are embedded with:
questions.explanation: In diatoms, the walls are embedded with silica and thus the walls are indestructible. This leads to accumulation called diatomaceous earth. (NCERT Page 14)

questions.question: Diatomaceous earth is used for:
questions.explanation: Being gritty, diatomaceous earth is used in polishing, filtration of oils and syrups. (NCERT Page 14)

questions.question: Red tides are caused by rapid multiplication of:
questions.explanation: Red dinoflagellates (Example: Gonyaulax) undergo rapid multiplication causing red tides. Toxins released may kill marine animals. (NCERT Page 15)

questions.question: Gonyaulax is an example of:
questions.explanation: Gonyaulax is a red dinoflagellate that causes red tides when it undergoes rapid multiplication. (NCERT Page 15)

questions.question: The protein-rich layer in Euglenoids that makes their body flexible is called:
questions.explanation: Euglenoids have a protein rich layer called pellicle instead of a cell wall, which makes their body flexible. (NCERT Page 15)

questions.question: Euglenoids show which type of nutrition?
questions.explanation: Euglenoids are photosynthetic in presence of sunlight but behave like heterotrophs when deprived of sunlight, showing mixotrophic nutrition. (NCERT Page 15)

questions.question: The aggregation formed by slime moulds under suitable conditions is called:
questions.explanation: Under suitable conditions, slime moulds form an aggregation called plasmodium which may grow and spread over several feet. (NCERT Page 15)

questions.question: Amoeboid protozoans move and capture prey using:
questions.explanation: Amoeboid protozoans move and capture their prey by putting out pseudopodia (false feet) as in Amoeba. (NCERT Page 15-16)

questions.question: Sleeping sickness is caused by:
questions.explanation: Flagellated protozoans like Trypanosoma are parasitic forms that cause diseases such as sleeping sickness. (NCERT Page 16)

questions.question: Paramoecium belongs to which group of protozoans?
questions.explanation: Paramoecium is a ciliated protozoan that is aquatic and actively moves due to presence of thousands of cilia. (NCERT Page 16)

questions.question: Plasmodium belongs to which group of protozoans?
questions.explanation: Plasmodium (malarial parasite) is a sporozoan that has an infectious spore-like stage in its life cycle. (NCERT Page 16)

questions.question: The network of hyphae in fungi is called:
questions.explanation: Fungal bodies consist of long, slender thread-like structures called hyphae. The network of hyphae is known as mycelium. (NCERT Page 16)

questions.question: Continuous tubes filled with multinucleated cytoplasm in fungi are called:
questions.explanation: Some hyphae are continuous tubes filled with multinucleated cytoplasm - these are called coenocytic hyphae. (NCERT Page 16)

questions.question: Fungi that live in association with roots of higher plants are called:
questions.explanation: Fungi can live as symbionts with roots of higher plants as mycorrhiza, and with algae as lichens. (NCERT Page 16)

questions.question: The fusion of protoplasms between two gametes in fungi is called:
questions.explanation: The sexual cycle in fungi involves: (i) Plasmogamy - fusion of protoplasms, (ii) Karyogamy - fusion of nuclei, (iii) Meiosis in zygote. (NCERT Page 17)

questions.question: The dikaryotic stage (n + n) occurs in:
questions.explanation: In ascomycetes and basidiomycetes, an intervening dikaryotic stage (n + n, two nuclei per cell) occurs. This condition is called dikaryon. (NCERT Page 17)

questions.question: Phycomycetes have which type of mycelium?
questions.explanation: In Phycomycetes, the mycelium is aseptate and coenocytic. They are found in aquatic habitats and moist places. (NCERT Page 17)

questions.question: Which of the following is a parasitic fungus on mustard?
questions.explanation: Albugo is the parasitic fungi on mustard. Mucor and Rhizopus are saprophytic Phycomycetes. (NCERT Page 17)

questions.question: Ascomycetes are commonly known as:
questions.explanation: Ascomycetes are commonly known as sac-fungi because their sexual spores (ascospores) are produced in sac-like asci. (NCERT Page 17)

questions.question: Which unicellular fungus belongs to Ascomycetes?
questions.explanation: Yeast (Saccharomyces) is a rarely unicellular ascomycete. Most ascomycetes are multicellular like Penicillium. (NCERT Page 17)

questions.question: Conidia in Ascomycetes are produced on special mycelium called:
questions.explanation: The asexual spores in Ascomycetes are conidia produced exogenously on special mycelium called conidiophores. (NCERT Page 18)

questions.question: Which organism is extensively used in biochemical and genetic work?
questions.explanation: Neurospora is used extensively in biochemical and genetic work. It is an ascomycete. (NCERT Page 18)

questions.question: Mushrooms belong to which class of fungi?
questions.explanation: Commonly known forms of basidiomycetes are mushrooms, bracket fungi or puffballs. (NCERT Page 18)

questions.question: In Basidiomycetes, plasmogamy occurs by fusion of:
questions.explanation: In Basidiomycetes, sex organs are absent, but plasmogamy is brought about by fusion of two vegetative or somatic cells of different strains. (NCERT Page 18)

questions.question: Ustilago (smut) belongs to which class of fungi?
questions.explanation: Common members of Basidiomycetes are Agaricus (mushroom), Ustilago (smut) and Puccinia (rust fungus). (NCERT Page 18)

questions.question: Puccinia is a:
questions.explanation: Puccinia is a rust fungus and belongs to Basidiomycetes. Ustilago is a smut fungus. (NCERT Page 18)

questions.question: Deuteromycetes are also called:
questions.explanation: Deuteromycetes are commonly known as imperfect fungi because only the asexual or vegetative phases are known. (NCERT Page 18)

questions.question: Deuteromycetes reproduce only by:
questions.explanation: Deuteromycetes reproduce only by asexual spores known as conidia. Sexual reproduction is unknown in this group. (NCERT Page 18)

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of Deuteromycetes?
questions.explanation: Alternaria, Colletotrichum and Trichoderma are examples of Deuteromycetes. Aspergillus is an Ascomycete. (NCERT Page 18)

questions.question: Cuscuta is an example of:
questions.explanation: Cuscuta is a parasite. Bladderwort and Venus fly trap are examples of insectivorous plants. (NCERT Page 19)

questions.question: The phenomenon of alternation between diploid sporophytic and haploid gametophytic phases in plants is called:
questions.explanation: Life cycle of plants has two distinct phases - diploid sporophytic and haploid gametophytic - that alternate. This is called alternation of generations. (NCERT Page 19)

questions.question: Animals store food reserves as:
questions.explanation: Animals digest their food in an internal cavity and store food reserves as glycogen or fat. (NCERT Page 19)

questions.question: Who first recognised viruses as causal organism of mosaic disease of tobacco?
questions.explanation: Dmitri Ivanowsky (1892) recognised certain microbes as causal organism of the mosaic disease of tobacco. (NCERT Page 20)

questions.question: The term 'Contagium vivum fluidum' was coined by:
questions.explanation: M.W. Beijerinck (1898) named the pathogen 'virus' and called the fluid as Contagium vivum fluidum (infectious living fluid). (NCERT Page 20)

questions.question: Who showed that viruses could be crystallised?
questions.explanation: W.M. Stanley (1935) showed that viruses could be crystallised and crystals consist largely of proteins. (NCERT Page 20)

questions.question: Plant viruses generally contain:
questions.explanation: Viruses that infect plants have single stranded RNA. Bacteriophages are usually double stranded DNA viruses. (NCERT Page 20)

questions.question: The protein coat of virus is called:
questions.explanation: The protein coat called capsid made of small subunits called capsomeres, protects the nucleic acid of viruses. (NCERT Page 20)

questions.question: Viroids were discovered by:
questions.explanation: In 1971, T.O. Diener discovered viroids - a new infectious agent smaller than viruses that caused potato spindle tuber disease. (NCERT Page 21)

questions.question: Viroids differ from viruses in that they:
questions.explanation: Viroids are free RNA and lack the protein coat that is found in viruses. The RNA of viroid is of low molecular weight. (NCERT Page 21)

questions.question: Potato spindle tuber disease is caused by:
questions.explanation: T.O. Diener discovered viroids that caused potato spindle tuber disease. (NCERT Page 21)

questions.question: Prions are:
questions.explanation: Prions are agents consisting of abnormally folded protein that cause infectious neurological diseases. (NCERT Page 21)

questions.question: Mad cow disease (BSE) is caused by:
questions.explanation: Bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) commonly called mad cow disease is caused by prions. (NCERT Page 21)

questions.question: The algal component in lichens is called:
questions.explanation: In lichens, the algal component is known as phycobiont and fungal component as mycobiont. (NCERT Page 21)

questions.question: Lichens are good indicators of:
questions.explanation: Lichens are very good pollution indicators - they do not grow in polluted areas. (NCERT Page 21)

questions.question: In lichens, the fungal component provides:
questions.explanation: In lichens, algae prepare food for fungi and fungi provide shelter and absorb mineral nutrients and water for its partner. (NCERT Page 21)
